page.title: 14Lacemaking in Turvey
page.content: Turvey was a commercial lace centre, producing and receiving lace made in surrounding villages. Dealers met here to buy and sell. In 1981 interest in lacemaking was revived with an exhibition of old lace bobbins, laces,threads and journalswhich had been found in the loft of a cottage. Classes meet weekly, some members are experienced and follow traditional Bedfordshire Lace designs,beginners start with a Torchon design. Bobbins and threads are bought at lace shops in Bedford or Olney or at annual Lace Days. Lace pillows were made of straw, but now polystyrene is often used instead. Bobbins vary in price from 9p for a plastic one to possibly Â£180 for an antique rarity such as 'a hanging bobbin' - commemorating a local hanging
